div1.p: [Carter] responds to a report on yellow fever outbreaks in the Guianas.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, January 20, 1924
div1.opener:
Surinam -- quoted by Corre
1863- 6 or 9?
Date of Maxcys paper?
I. H. B.
/LC
Epidemiology (the)
of
Yellow Fever
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
January 20, 1924.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I am in receipt of the letters and reports relative to fever
in the British Guianas, forwarded me by Miss Read on January 5th.,
and would thank you for the same--especially for the report by
Flu. This is extremely good and instructive--as, indeed, have
been all the papers that I have seen by him: above all his experi-
ments with aegypti mosquitoes in refrigerator ships.

No criticism or report on these letters is called for, and yet
there are one or two things in them to which I would invite your
attention:
1/ On Page 2 of Dr. Muensch's letter he quotes Dr. Blin,
Surgeon General of Cayenne, for there having been no yellow fever
in French Guiana since 1902. This, of course, may be correct,
but in 1916 - on the trip of the Y. F. Commission- both Guiteras and myself carried copies of the U. S.
Public Health Reports stating that there had been “----cases:
----deaths” from yellow fever at Maroni in French Guiana, occurring
the earlier part of that year or the latter part of 1915. Of
course, I don't guarantee the diagnosis, but yellow fever was re-
ported. Maroni is in the extreme north-western part of French Gui-
Gui-
-2-
ana, close to the Dutch.

Corre quotes Bajon that yellow fever was introduced into French
Fuiana in 1763, lasting to 1769, and Augustin quotes the same author,
and Campet, that it caused 1,143 deaths out of 2,361 Europeans in 1764,
Into Georgetown in the latter part of the XVlllth. Century--I could find
the exact date in my notes if worth while: Into Dutch Guiana (Surinam)
1760, according to, quoted by Corre.

British Guiana ceased to be a, more or less, permanent focus in the
latter quarter of the XlXth. Century, following--and probably on account
of--the introduction of water in pipes.-see Boyce

It is reasonably sure that all of these places had earlier intro-
ductions of yellow fever. They could hardly have escaped the wide-spread
“Epidemic of the Oriflamme” of 1690-'70, unless they had no aegypti at
that time.

With regard to that in Surinam (Dutch Guiana) I know much less.
There are reports in the latter part of the XVlllth. Century of its
occurring in Curacao and the mainland. It was, however, regarded as
an intense marsh poison and Moncey (Dutch Naval Surgeon) writing from
Curacao quotes, with his approbation “the judicious Pringle” (Sir John
Pringle, Chief Surgeon of the British Admiralty in these waters) to the
effect that there was no difference--save in intensity and the tempera-
ment of the patient--between the yellow fever; the marsh fevers; dysen-
teries and scurvy! Unless then we can make the diagnosis from the des-
cription given there is little use in investigating any what may have been called yellow fever in
the Guianas prior to Blair (1836 or '37), who was really a great epidem-
iologist.

With regard to Dr. Blin on the relation between the fievre bilieuse
inflammatoire--as doubtless you know--Guiteras and myself had been de-
tailed in 1917 to investigate this and other things in the French An-
An-
-3-
tilles and (le fiebre naya) in the Maracaibo: Cucuta and Coro region in Venezuela. The
War prevented this, but there is no doubt that this diagnosis is a kind
of omnium gatherum in French Latin America: It includes mild cases of
yellow fever, when yellow fever is present: dengue when dengue is pres-
ent: malarial fever, where blood examination is not made or recurrent
attacks do not do not make that diagnosis obligatory: embarras gastrique;
slight attacks of the sun among the newly arrived and any other acute
febrile attack which is not definitely something else. Thus, when it
was yellow fever it protected against yellow fever. Some cases clearly
did not, as witness a batallion (Corre) of 200 men raised in Martinique
and Guadeloupe in 1864, and supposed to be acclimatized by this fever,
198 of whom died of yellow fever in Vera Cruz: One had deserted and the
survivor was “disbanded” “par merci.”

One other thing: The over-lapping of dates alluded to by Dr.
Muensch (Page 3 of his report) simply implies that the three Guianas
plus the adjacent island had been a regional focus, some--maybe more
than one--part of which had been always infected and some always not in-
fected.

If the statement made by Flu is true--that the population is im-
munized after residence for a few years without the apparent presence of
yellow fever, we will have to admit that yellow fever was present in
such population sufficiently often for all--or practically all--of them
to have had the disease within the limits of residence found protective.
I can't think that any modern sanitarian is willing to go back to the
old idea of Mithridatism as a mechanism for Creole immunity. To quote
myself--which one should rarely do: “The visible links in the chain of
infections in a mixed black and white community--the blacks being in
large majority--should thus occur among the whites--generally newly ar-
rived whites. These visible links are not generally joined with each
each
-4-
other, but have, it maybe, between them a considerable number of invis-
ible links--the unrecongized infections in the blacks (especially
in the black children).” It is, however, we believe, a continuous
chain from one little out-break to another through these unrecogniz-
ed infections.

There are two fundamental errors--which seem to me very im-
portant ones--in the present French epidemiology of yellow fever and
which appear to be generally held in Latin America:--
1/ The one that has come down to us from old times that yel-
low fever is a mysterious disease developed from the soil and cli-
matic conditions (“telluric emanation”), to which one living in a
place where it is endemic, from the gradual empoisonment occurring
there acquires an immunity to the disease; which immunity will be
lost certainly by a prolonged or even moderate residence in a
place where it is not endemic or, according to some, even by moving
In 1899 & 1900 the Havanas beleived that they would contract y.f. in Vera Cruz & Vice Versa Beranger Fernaud (around 1875) preached the same doctrine
of Negrians changing their residence in W. Africa
from this endemic focus to another. This is the old “Mithridatism”
(the origin of the term is easily seen) which I thought had been
entirely set to rest by the work of Chaille and Guiteras, ably sup-
plemented by some of the French writers from St. Pierre.
2/ The absolute acceptance of the dictum of the Commission
of the Pasteur Institute, working at Rio (1903-'04) (or rather of
Simond and Salembini, for Marchoux had left them before this was
put out): viz--
“That the disease is continued in endemic areas by recurrent
attacks among the indigenes.” There is a further statement as-
as-
-5-
serting the common existence of carriers--the man not being sick of
the disease although infected with it.

For neither of these beliefs did these gentlemen advance one
single observation nor--so far as I know--has any ever been advanc-
ed, save by Seidelin, who regarded the presence of his Paraplasma
flavigenum as proof of infection with yellow fever.

There is much loose data to the contrary of the statement
given in “ ” in the experience and writings of men familiar with
this disease, although the only systematic argument against it is, I
think, that on “Immunity to Yellow Fever,” Journal of Tropical Medi-
cine and Parisitoloty, April, 1916, a copy of which you have. This
is, I think, fairly convincing, though as it is necessarily nega-
tive evidence, each one must judge for himself on this.

It grieves me to find the French--of all people!--abandoning
their own great writers: Dutrolau: Moreau de Jonnés: Cornilliac:
Rufz de Lav: ??? Late Corre: Béranger Féraud: Roux, and even the French-
men who wrote (in French) from U. S. experience, like Faget; old
Touatre and Chaillé--men who spent all their professional lives with
yellow fever--and accepting without any question a statement by
men who had seen very little of it and who advanced not a single
observation to confirm that statement.

This last heresy is as obvious in West Africa as it is in the
Guianas.
